titlStmt.titl: Data for Chiming In: Social Presence in an International Multisite Blended Learning Course

citation.biblCit: MacIsaac, Peggy Lynn, 2021, "Data for Chiming In: Social Presence in an International Multisite Blended Learning Course", https://doi.org/10.7939/DVN/FHOMRF, UAL Dataverse, V1, UNF:6:sBEA2TcDOrRARoHg9phuxQ== [fileUNF]

titlStmt.titl: Data for Chiming In: Social Presence in an International Multisite Blended Learning Course

stdyInfo.abstract: These are WhatsApp mobile instant messaging chats between refugee and non-refugee learners in one 2018 summer term York University undergraduate course offered through the Borderless Higher Education for Refugees Program. The learners are attributed to a country of location while studying, a gender, a final grade, and a chat group which was composed for the purposes of supporting a group presentation. Refugee learners were based in Kenya and Thailand, while none refugees were based in Canada. More learners were in the groups than were participants in the study. Non-participants' data and chats were removed from the groups. The chat messages are attributed to a learner, a date and time, and then coded for the indicators of social presence as described by the Community of Inquiry Framework.

citation.biblCit: MacIsaac, P. L. (2021). Chiming In: Social presence in an international multi-site blended learning course (Doctoral dissertation, Athabasca University). http://hdl.handle.net/10791/348
